meanings.def: to put your hand or another part of your body onto somebody/something
examples: Don't touch that plate—it's hot!
Can you touch your toes? (= bend and reach them with your hands)
touch somebody on something I touched him lightly on the arm.
touch somebody/something with something Do not touch anything with your bare hands.
He has hardly touched the ball all game.
(figurative) I must do some more work on that article—I haven't touched it all week.
Don't you dare touch me!
He accidentally touched a live wire attached to overhead power cables.
He did not actually touch the substance, but may have inhaled it.
He was close enough to touch her.
He wouldn't let me touch the wound.
Her hand reached out to touch his cheek.
His fingers briefly touched hers.
She hugged him, being careful not to touch his broken wrist.
In social groups, dolphins often touch each other with their pectoral fins.

meanings.def: to be or come so close together that there is no space between
examples: Make sure the wires don't touch.
Their faces were almost touching.
touch something Don't let your coat touch the wet paint.
His coat was so long it was almost touching the floor.
The dancer’s feet hardly seemed to touch the ground.

meanings.def: to move something, especially in such a way that you damage it; to hit or harm somebody
examples: I told you not to touch my things.
He said I kicked him, but I never touched him!

meanings.def: to make somebody feel upset or emotional
examples: touch somebody/something Her story touched us all deeply.
What he said really touched my heart.
I had been touched by his kindness to my aunts.
touch somebody/something to do something It truly touches me to know that I am holding in my hand a piece of paper used by someone who lived in 1745.

meanings.def: to affect somebody/something
examples: These are issues that touch us all.
The life of a shepherd has been only marginally touched by technological change.
Even the most remote areas are now directly touched by political, educational and medical advances.

meanings.def: to eat, drink or use something
examples: You've hardly touched your food.
He hasn't touched the money his aunt left him.

meanings.def: to be as good as somebody in skill, quality, etc.
examples: No one can touch him when it comes to interior design.

meanings.def: to reach a particular level, etc.
examples: The speedometer was touching 90.

meanings.def: to become connected with or work with a situation or person
examples: Everything she touches turns to disaster.
His last two movies have been complete flops and now no studio will touch him.

meanings.def: to be seen on somebody’s face for a short time
examples: A smile touched the corners of his mouth.

meanings.def: to have a small amount of a particular quality
examples: His hair was touched with grey.
Some of her poems are touched with real genius.

meanings.def: to upset somebody by reminding them of something they are particularly sensitive about
to mention a subject that makes somebody feel angry, upset, embarrassed, etc.
examples: You touched a raw nerve when you mentioned his first wife.
My remarks about divorce had unwittingly touched a raw nerve.
The article struck a raw nerve as it revived unpleasant memories.

meanings.def: to not hurt somebody physically in any way
to refuse to get involved with somebody/something or in a particular situation
examples: Personally, I wouldn’t touch him or his business with a bargepole.

meanings.def: to say or do something that makes people feel sympathy or enthusiasm
examples: The speaker had obviously struck a chord with his audience.

meanings.def: to make contact with somebody again
to reach the ground at the bottom of an area of water
examples: I put my feet down and touched bottom.

meanings.def: to reach the worst possible state or condition
examples: Her career really touched bottom with that movie.

meanings.def: to say or do something that makes people feel sympathy or enthusiasm
examples: The speaker had obviously touched a chord with his audience.

meanings.def: to show too much respect for somebody of a higher class, especially because you are anxious about what they think of you
used when talking about your previous good luck or your hopes for the future, to avoid bringing bad luck
examples: I've been driving for over 20 years and never had an accident—touch wood!

meanings.def: very close
examples: We came within touching distance of winning the cup.
We live within spitting distance of the bus station.

idioms.def: to have a small amount of a particular quality
examples: His hair was touched with grey.
Some of her poems are touched with real genius.

idioms.def: very close
examples: We came within touching distance of winning the cup.
We live within spitting distance of the bus station.

meanings.def: the sense that enables you to be aware of things and what they are like when you put your hands and fingers on them
examples: the sense of touch
by touch They had to identify various materials by touch.
Sculpture potentially appeals to the sense of touch as well as sight.
The bird depends largely on an extremely delicate sense of touch to find its prey.
She has learnt to recognize the raised patterns of Braille by touch.

meanings.def: an act of putting your hand or another part of your body onto somebody/something
examples: The gentle touch of his hand on her shoulder made her jump.
at the touch of somebody/something All this information is readily available at the touch of a button (= by simply pressing a button).
at somebody's touch The door swung open at his touch.
This type of engraving requires a delicate touch.
She played the piano with a light touch.
The slightest touch will set off the alarm.

meanings.def: the way that something feels when you put your hand or fingers on it or when it comes into contact with your body
examples: material with a smooth silky touch
He could not bear the touch of clothing on his sunburnt skin.
to the touch The body was cold to the touch.

meanings.def: a small detail that is added to something in order to improve it or make it complete
examples: Meeting them at the airport was a nice touch.
Bright cushions add a decorative touch to a room.
The family photos add a homely touch.
The candles gave the table a romantic touch.
The decor includes many idiosyncratic little touches.

meanings.def: a way or style of doing something
examples: She prefers to answer any fan mail herself for a more personal touch.
Computer graphics will give your presentation the professional touch.
He couldn't find his magic touch with the ball today (= he didn't play well).
This meal is awful. I think I'm losing my touch (= my ability to do something).
He found his old political touch when the crisis emerged.
He must regain his shooting touch.
She seemed to have a deft touch with comedy.
With students she had a sure touch and showed great personal sensitivity.
a politician who lacked the common touch

meanings.def: a very small amount
examples: There was a touch of sarcasm in her voice.
There could be a touch of frost tonight.
He has just the right touch of arrogance for the role.
Her speech brought a welcome touch of frivolity to the evening.
Give your garden a touch of class with a sundial as a focal point.

meanings.def: slightly; a little
examples: The music was a touch too loud for my liking.

meanings.def: the area outside the lines that mark the sides of the playing field
examples: into touch He kicked the ball into touch.

meanings.def: to not know or understand what is happening in a particular subject or area
examples: Unfortunately, the people making the decisions are out of touch with the real world.
This government is increasingly out of touch with ordinary voters.

meanings.def: to communicate with somebody, especially by writing to them or phoning them
examples: Are you still in touch with your friends from college?
Thanks for showing us your products—we'll be in touch.
I'm trying to get in touch with Jane. Do you have her number?
Let's keep in touch.
I'll put you in touch with someone in your area.
The security staff were in close touch with the local police.

meanings.def: to know what is happening in a particular subject or area
examples: It is important to keep in touch with the latest research.

meanings.def: to no longer communicate with somebody, so that you no longer know what is happening to them
examples: We’ve been out of touch for a couple of years.

meanings.def: the ability of a powerful or famous person to talk to and understand ordinary people
a person that you can easily persuade to do something, especially to give you money
examples: Unfortunately, my father is no soft touch.

meanings.def: to reject something or treat it as not important; to stop dealing with a problem
examples: He tends to deal with disputes by kicking them into the long grass.

meanings.def: the ability to deal with something in a sensitive and relaxed way
examples: She handles this difficult subject with a light touch.

meanings.def: to no longer have any contact with somebody/something
examples: I've lost touch with all my old friends.

meanings.def: to no longer understand something, especially how ordinary people feel
